8/ “If you must collect some PII [personal identifiable information] for business purposes, purge it as quickly as possible to minimize the amount of data you have on hand at any time," advises @lopp.

RTWT by CoinDesk privacy reporter @benjaminopowers: 

https://t.co/F2HTPIE6oD

7/ In @lopp's view, holding email addresses long term for marketing purposes is understandable, though holding names, physical addresses, and phone numbers of customers once a delivery is complete and the return window expired is harder to justify. 
https://t.co/F2HTPIE6oD

6/As rivals like @COLDCARDwallet, seemingly in response to the @Ledger leak, announced they would wipe user data after a certain period, @_pgauthier questioned the legality of such actions; tax requirements mandate some data be kept 10 years, he said. https://t.co/F2HTPIE6oD

5/In an interview @_pgauthier emphasized first and foremost how sorry he was that the hack and leak of @ledger customer data occurred. He and incoming CISO Matt Johnson will announce a new data policy and plan to further address the leaks in January.
https://t.co/F2HTPIE6oD

4/To put such threats in perspective, @Ledger CEO @_pgauthier says the company saw those emails go out in multiple languages, meaning the likelihood someone would actually try to physically attack a user was slim. IOW, they may just be phishing attempts.
https://t.co/F2HTPIE6oD

3/ Even more ominously, some users have received physical threats. In one instance, a @Ledger user allegedly received an email from someone trying to extort their cryptocurrency by saying they were “not afraid to invade their home.”
https://t.co/F2HTPIE6oD

2/ @jimbochewdip describes a Kafkaesque experience after his personal data was exposed in the @Ledger leak. “By the time I got into my Coinbase Pro account and checked the balance, there had been a sale of the coins I held." $2K of his crypto, gone. https://t.co/F2HTPIE6oD

IN DEPTH: Lesson of the @ledger leak? “Don’t collect what you can’t protect — personal information should be treated like toxic waste,” says @lopp.

Report by @benjaminopowers

https://t.co/eFlPJGZmwQ

And it all started with one clever idea, laid out in eight pages. (Nine if you count the footnotes.)

#Bitcoin

This stateless, neutral money has supported dissident publishers like @wikileaks, enabled the rise of the Silk Road and is the primary source of income for Sci-Hub pirate @ringo_ring. It exists for good and bad actors alike.

https://t.co/oizkdxSxTA

#Bitcoin is perhaps the only stateless, neutral money to achieve a very simple goal: 

Creating a dependable financial system that anyone can access without exception or fear of censorship - so long as they have an internet connection.

“That most people still hate bitcoin isn’t a bad thing,” said @dylangrice of Calderwood Capital in The Economist. 

https://t.co/4z5NgvnpWU

Since then, Bitcoin has been called many things: a scam, a Ponzi scheme, dead on arrival, a joke, a tool for criminals, rat poisoned squared, a currency for geeks – and did we mention dead?

https://t.co/RECcibsA2s

Presented, with little fanfare, to a small cadre of cypherpunks over the cryptographer’s mailing list, Satoshi’s document has since sparked a monetary revolution.

https://t.co/cxQAhpdzyJ

Halloween 2020 marks the 12th anniversary of the #Bitcoin white paper – the first time the concept of a fully decentralized, peer-to-peer electronic cash system passed from Satoshi Nakamoto’s mind to the world.

.@AsILayHodling explores this topic in depth in part two of our series on Lightning Network vulnerabilities:

https://t.co/1H09XvtOpu

As Lightning grows and builders try to strike a balance between user-friendliness and security, addressing these attacks will require careful deliberation.
 
And maybe a bit of pressure from adversaries, @joostjgr thinks, could help set security priorities for development.

Some of these attack vectors will be less vulnerable thanks to Lightning's new “anchor channels," which will allow users to update fees on the go when closing channels.
 
This update, though, has exposed a new vulnerability, a reminder that innovation can create complications.

Since they are so difficult to pull off, they haven't been a priority.
 
“It almost feels like you’re going to prepare Earth for a meteor that will destroy life but it hasn’t happened! If there’s no actual attack then it’s hard to keep attention on these problems." 
-@joostjgr

For most hackers, these exploits are either too difficult to pull off or don't provide enough loot to justify the effort. And those with the expertise - the developers building on Lightning - are more focused on collaboration than subterfuge.

The Lightning Network has attack vectors that have never been exploited.
 
Why have the vulnerabilities been left untouched? 
 
A thread on why Lightning has never weathered an attack, and what can be done about the existing attack vectors. 🧵👇 https://t.co/jNaOP9QKxa

How concerned are you about Lightning vulnerabilities?

Why have none of these vulnerabilities ever been exploited in the wild?
 
That’s something we’ll answer in part two, as well as discuss potential fixes and why a little adversarial pressure might be good to harden the network's defense. ⌛️

4. Another attack that requires incomplete transaction data: the pinning attack. 

To exploit this vulnerability, a sophisticated attacker could block a channel’s closing transaction by broadcasting conflicting transactions to nodes that aren’t connected with each other. https://t.co/iFXvyZtCjU

3. The time-dilation attack, the most complex and serious of the bunch, requires a “sybil attack” on a victim’s Lightning node.

With the node’s connections “eclipsed,” the attacker can feed it transaction data at a slower rate in hopes of stealing funds from closing LN channels. https://t.co/mgLm6rzgIl

2. For a “flood and loot” attack, an attacker would spam routed payments through a victim’s node and force close each channel together. If any of the closing transactions failed when broadcasted on-chain, the attacker could claim them by re-sending the same BTC with a higher fee. https://t.co/zlI0ToKZA2

1. “Griefing” attacks have been possible since Lightning's launch and involve freezing the funds in a payment channel by maxing out its HTLC limit.
 
Relative to other Lightning vulnerabilities, griefing isn’t as threatening as attackers can only freeze funds, not steal them. https://t.co/fQl0V7pKDj

Developers have discovered a number of vulnerabilities in Bitcoin’s Lightning Network over the years. Some are more serious than others, most are very tricky to pull off and none have been exploited.
 
Here's how these attack vectors work 🧵👇
 
https://t.co/xDbahzf4Ym https://t.co/36KGfcIAXM

The #bitcoin community protested these moves in characteristically dramatic fashion.

https://t.co/eCTFZM4bru

Shortly thereafter, Fancy, an e-commerce platform, removed #bitcoin payments from its iOS app at @Apple’s request.

https://t.co/SyMcpvqpUE

In early 2014, @blockchain’s app got the boot, as did Australian wallet provider @GetCoinJar. 

https://t.co/xIo1zbsSIh

Also in late 2013, privacy app @Gli_ph had to remove a #bitcoin payment option to stay in the iOS app store.  

https://t.co/u1i1rkmJLv

(It was later reinstated. Around the height of the 2017 bull run, @Coinbase’s app was No. 1 in the iOS store.)

https://t.co/ic6CIaS0cJ

Nevertheless, it is clear @Apple was once averse to anything #bitcoin-related. 

In November 2013, for example, @Coinbase’s iOS app was removed from the app store less than a month after its debut.

https://t.co/ooCpzKFQF7

To be fair, @Apple often takes strong measures to protect users. In 2015, it suspended a game where players could win in-game tokens and tip other gamers in BTC. Apple feared users would mistake one for the other.

https://t.co/L4ihzChCow

.@FortniteGame maker @EpicGames sued @Apple this week for allegedly hampering competition in its app store and payments.

https://t.co/bJ97Bznyqh

Other factors affect mining. Although China remains the leading region for bitcoin mining, the coronavirus downturn is changing the picture in other geographies:

https://t.co/8GspPRe839

However, rising energy costs mean miners in places with expensive electricity might get priced out. Electricity in China is 40% cheaper per household than the US:

@GlobalPetrol @coindeskdata #BitcoinHalving https://t.co/R2JZZql8vg

While the number of new coins mined is cut in half, revenue isn’t necessarily cut by half. As bitcoin’s value compared to USD has increased, so has miner revenue:
@coinmetrics @coindeskdata #BitcoinHalving https://t.co/lF5Vq9rzt6

The four biggest mining pools - @f2pool_official, Poolin, @AntPoolofficial and @ViaBTC, all in China - hold 50-60% of all hashing power.

@btccom_official @coindeskdata #BitcoinHalving https://t.co/bXmbDsOXiN

Miners need the network to have value so they can earn these rewards. They have incentive to maintain its integrity; if trust in bitcoin goes down, so do their rewards. It’s a built-in disincentive to collude.

@btccom_official @coindeskdata #BitcoinHalving https://t.co/NPKFmBelW5

Miners earn bitcoin for every block they produce. The peak was on Dec. 17, 2017, when miners earned over $54 million: 

@coinmetrics @coindeskdata #BitcoinHalving https://t.co/5HJ5u0GPbC

In a one-year span, bitcoin outperforms many traditional assets:

@coinmetrics @coindeskdata @stlouisfed #BitcoinHalving https://t.co/KJQN5F8oh0

Both times thus far, the #BitcoinHalving has coincided with a price rise:

@coinmetrics @coindeskdata https://t.co/ZuqbupGqlg

The next #BitcoinHalving is fast approaching. The Bitcoin block mining subsidy will be cut in half roughly every four years until all 21 million coins are mined. Will Bitcoin Halving 2020 push up the price? 

@coindeskdata’s Research Report, released today, dives in: 🧵👇 https://t.co/10Nfhcks8T
